newsitem.title: USA: Iraq opts for Australian wheat after cancelling U.S. deal.
newsitem.headline: Iraq opts for Australian wheat after cancelling U.S. deal.

text.p: Iraq on Monday night cancelled a purchase of 150,000 tonnes U.S. hard red winter wheat and switched the purchase to 100,000 to up to 150,000 tonnes of Australian hard wheat, several U.S. exporters said.

"They cancelled 150,000 tonnes of ours and bought 150,000 Australian," a senior wheat trader said on Tuesday. "I believe they did this last night. They said there was an irregularity in the contract but it is probably on the price," he added.
A second wheat exporter said: "We were under the impression that Iraq bought up to 100,000 tonnes late last week but then they apparently cancelled that and replaced it with Australian, so we hear."

European traders said May 29 that Iraq had bought 150,000 tonnes of U.S. hard red winter wheat for July shipment at $194 C+F. The transaction was part of the United Nations agreement allowing Iraq to sell oil to buy food and supplies.
Delivery dates were unavailable and no other details were immediately available.
